channel.title: Data Science Portfolio on Henry Truong
channel.description: Recent content in Data Science Portfolio on Henry Truong

item.title: TidyTuesday: UFC History
item.description: This work is inspired and instructed by Andrew Couch. I would like to express my deepest appreciation to him. The topic is about UFC Match History. The data can be accessed via this link. The work focuses on cleaning data, performing exploratory analysis, building and tweaking a model and further performing exploratory analysis. Codes used for this work can be found in my github. There are 3 main questions will be answered:

item.title: TidyTuesday: Chocolate Ratings
item.description: This work is inspired by R Data Science: Tidy Tuesday. This weekâ€™s topic is about Chocolate Ratings. The data can be accessed via this link. The work will answer three main questions related to: How each continent in the world contribute to the origin of chocolate What words and how they are used describe the chocolate taste Whether we can build a predictive models using text data along with other features to predict chocolate ratings The work walks through all the steps of a typical data science project, which include:

item.title: R Project: Predictive Text Model
item.description: This topic of this project is to develop a data product predicting the next word when users are texting on their smartphone keyboard. The database used to train the model can be accessed via this link. The database is comprised of 4 sub-databases, each of which corresponds to each language. In this project, the focus is on the English sub-database. The text data within the English sub-database are collected from 3 different types of media:

item.title: TidyTuesday: Tuskegee Airmen
item.description: This work is inspired by R Data Science: Tidy Tuesday. This week’s topic is about Tuskegee Airmen. The data can be accessed via this link. The work will answer two questions related to: Spatial distribution of airmen across the US Correlation between the graduation rank and the type of pilot The work walks through all the steps of a typical data science project, which include: Getting the Data Understanding the Data Cleaning and Wrangling the Data Performing Exploratory Data Analysis Testing Hypothesis and Performing Statistical Inference The source code can be found in my GitHub.

item.title: R Project: Traffic Collisions in Halifax Regional Municipality
item.description: This topic of this project is on traffic collisions in Halifax Regional Municipality (HRM) over the period of 2018-2021. The project will find out the tendency of traffic accidents in terms of time, space as well as characteristics related to collisions, roads and drivers. In addition, the project will perform hypothesis testing to make inference from the data of HRM. Lastly, a predictive model will be built to make a prediction on the number of daily incidents occurring in HRM.

item.title: Python Project: Athletes and Results of 120 Years of Olympic History
item.description: The purpose of this project is to understand and examine the dataset on Athletes and Results of 120 Years of Olympic History using the data analysis approach. A large part of tools applied in this study include Python and SQL to get and clean the data, to make queries to extract a certain piece of information of interest, to perform exploratory data analysis and to create visualization of the extracted data.

item.title: R Project: Languages in Canada in 2016
item.description: This topic of this project is to develop a data product using the data set related to languages spoken by Canadian residents. This data set was collected during the 2016 Canadian census. The result of the project is an application used to visualize the answers of the following 2 questions: What are the top 3-10 languages of the selected category spoken most as mother tongue? What is the number of people speaking a language at work, given the number of them speaking it at home?
